hints_html: Break up the integral and use the fundamental theorem of calculus part 1.
hints_latex:
Break up the integral and use the fundamental theorem of calculus part
1.
hints_raw: Break up the integral and use the fundamental theorem of calculus part 1.
question: 1 (k)
sols_html:
Using the fundamental theorem of calculus and the chain rule, we have

\[\begin{aligned} f'(x) &= \frac{d}{dx} \int_{x}^{x^{2}} \sqrt{t^{4}+1}\, dt \\ &= \frac{d}{dx} \int_{x}^{0} \sqrt{t^{4}+1}\, dt + \frac{d}{dx} \int_{0}^{x^{2}} \sqrt{t^{4}+1}\, dt \\ &= \frac{d}{dx} -\int_{0}^{x} \sqrt{t^{4}+1}\, dt + \frac{d}{dx} \int_{0}^{x^{2}} \sqrt{t^{4}+1}\, dt \\ &= -\sqrt{x^{4}+1} + 2x \sqrt{x^{8}+1} \end{aligned}\]

.

Plugging in \(x=1\) yields

\[\begin{aligned} f'(1) &= -\sqrt{1^{4}+1} + 2(1) \sqrt{(1)^{8}+1} \\ &= -\sqrt{2} + 2\sqrt{2} \\ &= \sqrt{2} \end{aligned}\]

completing the question.
sols_raw:
Using the fundamental theorem of calculus and the chain rule, we have

:<math> 
\begin{align}
f'(x) &= \frac{d}{dx} \int_{x}^{x^{2}} \sqrt{t^{4}+1}\, dt \\
&= \frac{d}{dx} \int_{x}^{0} \sqrt{t^{4}+1}\, dt + \frac{d}{dx} \int_{0}^{x^{2}} \sqrt{t^{4}+1}\, dt \\
&= \frac{d}{dx} -\int_{0}^{x} \sqrt{t^{4}+1}\, dt + \frac{d}{dx} \int_{0}^{x^{2}} \sqrt{t^{4}+1}\, dt \\
&= -\sqrt{x^{4}+1} + 2x \sqrt{x^{8}+1} \\
\end{align}
</math>.

Plugging in <math> x=1 </math> yields

:<math> 
\begin{align}
f'(1) &= -\sqrt{1^{4}+1} + 2(1) \sqrt{(1)^{8}+1} \\
&= -\sqrt{2} + 2\sqrt{2} \\
&= \sqrt{2} \\
\end{align}
</math>

completing the question.
